messageBody:
Ilja wrote:

> *If* you do have a process/people problem, though, I don't think that
> tinkering with Junit is the best solution. The mass of failing tests is
> only a symptom, and by trying to fix it with Junit, you will only cure
> the symptom, not the real problem. By solving the real problem, the need
> to change the way Junit works will vanish. In fact, aggravating the
> problem by letting more tests fail due to a single problem might
> actually *help* you solve the real problem (by making it more visible).
> *If* you do have a process/people problem.

I can see that, for some more stable situations. The situation I had was
that I was undertaking a major (major) refactor of some core things that I
didn't consider clean & couldn't live with. I knew I was going to break some
major things, and was *very glad* I had a large working test suite before I
started it. Being test infected I felt empowered to make the huge change &
that junit would help me do it quickly, with damage control, and a
confidence at the end that my contracts with the outside world wouldn't have
been broken.

> So, tell us more about those failing tests?

I broke my core, re-designed it, re-wrote it -- no holds bars I dived in.
Loved it, felt much better for the refactor. Then it was "clean-up time",
time to put my tests back in order. I waded through the mass of failed tests
... and where to start, which first? Basically I tried working "bottom up",
ensuring a stabilizing foundation. I realized I was having to figure this
out from knowing the code, knowing the packages. TestCases "store" my
contract knowledge, but not more -- they don't help this part of the major
refactor.

As such, I had my little epiphany on dependency. Why can't testcases express
their own dependencies also & give "starting places" after a major refactor.
Hence I posted here...

regards

Adam
